comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I'm an Australian, and that does indeed look like a set of Kelly gang armour.. Here's an interesting article about the ship SUCCESS and the armour: glenrowan1880.com/success.htm It suggets that a replica copy of the armour was displayed on the ship, although it was purported to the viewing public to be genuine. Notably, some the LOC Bain collection photographs appear at that internet link.. The photographs appear oto have made their way there independent of the LOC. More on the ship SUCCESS here too: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Success_(prison_ship)

comment.author: 22345824@N00
35945984@N00
comment._content: I agree that it is probably a replica. The helmet is an odd shape at the base. The chest piece is missing some of the parts that Ned Kelly built into his original. This includes holes for shoulder straps and a curved edge of the lower edge from by the original shape of the mouldboard or plough. The iron skirt is attached by two, not one strap. In addition, the replica seems to have a extra back skirt panel. The shoulder pads were designed to protect the upper arm and from what I can see they were not bolted on to protect the top of the shoulder. My guess is that somebody had some fun reconstructing this from a drawing in a newspaper. It would be interesting to see how accurate the newspaper drawings were and if any depicts these same errors. If anybody is curious, there is also a good video here that details a suit of armor used by these bush-rangers. www.slv.vic.gov.au/collections/treasures/kelly_armour/kel...

comment.author: 90719112@N00
comment._content: My research also suggests that this is a replica. By the way, anyone wanting to know about this extraordinary vessel can read all about it on my website and blog. Rich Norgard www.shipsuccess.com www.shipsuccess.blogspot.com
